title: How Being a Twin Has Shaped My Psoriasis Journey

content: I have always been grateful to have been born with my best friend. Being a twin definitely creates a unique and special bond. This bond is unlike any other, hands down, in my book. Yes, we share clothes, shoes, jewelry, and yes, we both share in having psoriasis.

Although my sister’s psoriasis has been milder than mine, we both understand each other's challenges when it comes to the condition. I truly believe having my twin sister has been a saving grace for me with my psoriasis. We’ve had a ready-made, two-person community to connect with and relate to. It is what has helped me in my journey as a mentor for others with psoriasis.

I never realized growing up with an instant playmate would prepare me to be a part of and lead a community. As the oldest by five minutes, I’m the self-proclaimed leader between me and my sister. We often faced many challenges growing up, like bullying and self-doubt. It was my sister who I leaned on for support.

content: As I experienced my worst flares, my twin was my sounding board and comfort. Because she has psoriasis, she understands how it makes you feel inside and the physical pain symptoms from burning and itching. For this reason alone, it's been easy for me to connect with her even now if I am struggling.

Volunteering as a one-to-one mentor with the National Psoriasis Foundation, I realized that my twin was my unofficial one-to-one mentor. The same way she has been there for me, I’m there for my mentees. Never did I imagine that it would all come full circle in that way.

No one is an island. We all need each other for support, especially when living with a chronic condition. As I reflect, my experience growing up with my twin solidified the foundation of community and support. I believe this foundation has also been what has helped me to create The PsoriaSis Collective and the Sistas With Psoriasis support group.

content: I understood early why it was important to have someone to connect with, and why it was important to pass that on to others. So many people deal with so much more than the physical aspect of psoriasis. A lot of people are managing depression and may even isolate themselves. Community creates the safe space that is so desperately needed.

My twin has also helped me with the little things, like doing the dishes if I needed her to, or randomly driving me to the beach for doctor’s orders of natural vitamin D. She’s the best Auntie and has even taken my children to activities if needed. With my sister, I don’t even have to say anything is wrong – she can see it since she knows me so well. When she notices something is off, she goes into what she does best: pouring strength into me in any way I may need. It definitely makes the difference for me, especially when I know I can put my Superwoman cape down because she is there for me.

content: I am so thankful there are support groups, as well as organizations such as the National Psoriasis Foundation, that can offer resources for those who may feel alone. It’s incredibly important that these exist. Many people may not have the same level of support and resources available to them as I do, having my twin. Having access to support means so much.

Having my twin sister has shaped my psoriasis journey in ways that truly benefit everyone I encounter. I’ve been able to provide for and support others the way she has for me. Experiencing that connection and her also having an understanding of living with psoriasis has made a difference.

No twin? No problem! You can find others who can be just as helpful and understanding. There are several groups and organizations out there to offer support and help you build community. I am glad the universe recognized that I needed a twin sister by my side. I believe that I have been my absolute best self to others because of her. It’s my gift to now give that back to others.
